												I rarely do this, but felt compelled to write a short review.I love this game. It feels like a hybrid between Final Fantasy Tactics and The Oregon Trail. Both great games I remember from my youth (I'm almost 30).Its tough! I finally finished the game on my 4th play through. And am starting my 5th play through (Alt Endings).It is not terribly long game, about 8 hoursish; a bit shorter if you rush through dialog and skip some optional battles.Most game reviews will highlight the Artwork and Music, both exceptional.  I would like to highlight the mythology and just sense of purpose the characters, dialog, story, give the overall feel of the game.Tons of fun, worth the price, and it is rumored its the first part of a Trilogy.  Ill be there for part II.A little backstory, the developers of the game worked on the original Star Wars: The Old Republic game. Another great title for its generation.  Was a Kickstarter.  Met its funding goal in about 24hours.  The 3 main developers were former Bioware employees.  Who doesn't love Bioware games.In a nutshell, if your on the fence, I highly suggest The Banner Saga.  Lots of replay ability (there are some conversation choices that literally have played out 4 different ways, for me at least). Tons of fun, especially if you enjoy the afore mentioned Turn Based Strategy, Oregon Trial like survival, or a great story focusing on a makeshift Norse mythology.4.5/5Cheers!

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
12, 2016
												An emotive and beautiful journey through Viking legend, this game stands out both as an excellent strategy game, and as a true work of art. The hand-drawn artwork is sublime, and highly original in today's 3D obsessed world. The cast of dozens are beautifully rendered and animated, and set in the backdrop of a beautiful world in turmoil. The gods are dead, the sun has stopped, and something evil is coming.The story sucks you in, and challenges you with difficult moral and tactical choices throughout the game. Not only must you prevail on the battlefield, you must protect, feed and care for a growing caravan of refugees fleeing the evil on your tail. As your caravan traverses the beautiful windswept landscape you watch the narrative unfold, with each choice impacting on your fighting capability, morale, and dwindling food supplies.There are no easy choices. I am writing this review after my second playthrough, and can better appreciate this. The story is essentially linear, but seemingly innocuous choices could end the life of your favourite hero, or leave you with a knife in your back. Most games give hints to possible outcomes; The Banner Saga teaches you that life is arbitrary, cruel, and that you can't save everyone. The only consolation is perhaps that no matter how bad things get, none of your choices can (I think) make the game unwinnable - but you will live with the burden of knowing that had you chosen more wisely, perhaps more lives could have been saved.Combat is turn based, and, until the get the hang of it, pretty brutal. In another nod to realism, health and attack strength is linked - an injury means your hero can't hit as hard. As your team is weakened, each successive wound compounds upon the last, spiralling you closer to defeat. Battles can be nail-biting affairs, but the tension this mechanic creates is delicious, and makes prevailing all the sweeter. My only criticism is that there were too many monotonous battles mid-game, but perservere, and your skills and your heroes will be honed for your ultimate confrontation in the last chapter.Despite its minor flaws, I thoroughly enjoyed this game; twice. Each path taken was another surprise, and deepened my appreciation of the thought, effort and love that went into this accomplished KickStarter project. A fantastic and memorable experience, and a big thumbs up from me.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
15, 2014
												So this game....is great! I have many kind words to say about this and being a huge Final Fantasy Tactics(SRPG's for that matter) fan this was a real treat to see on Steam's front page one day. I have some things about the game I love and I have some things about the game...well that I actually hate. Yes, it has left that much distaste in my mouth haha but thats not to discourage you. It is most likely something formed from my biased and practically purist views of SRPG's. So first, the things I love ^_^1-The ArtCant say enough about this, its phenomenal and its like being in an interactive Disney game of brutality and brings me back to the SegaCD days and old PC of point and click adventure/exploring days. I could easily say; play this game to just be immensed inside this beautiful game. 2-The MusicIt's very well composed and suited for everything thats going on in this story and era its cast in. I'm a musician/composer myself and cant help but appreciate it from that sense, but I would imagine most people who arent into music would only be pulled into the feelings of this game easier similar to a Hollywood movie.3-SRPG ElementsWell..... I love this aspect of the game and its 90% of the reason I bought this game. I've played every SRPG I can get my hands on from Fire Emblem series and Final Fantasy Tactics to the overly diluted systems of Ogre Tactics and Disgaea. While I prefer a system that is well thought out with its boundaries and expansions within its systems, I do sometimes prefer a bit more of openness in the system such as Disgaea, but my mind tends to grow bored with endless options as everything becomes bland quicker than key roles that tend to shine within a system with some boundaries. Back to this game though, its set up a bit differently. The classes are chosen ahead of time, if you can even call them classes, more like roles from the characters backgrounds. Archers,Bruisers,Tanks,Lancers,etc are some things you can expect to see early game. All with their own special moves and ranges on the map as well as movement across the map.4-The Story TellingIts great and very reminiscent of a great game that allows you to feel as if you have some control of the outlook of the characters,story,and ending. Games that come to mind are those of the Bethesda Series of Fallout and Elder Scrolls. Killing of key characters, ignoring causes for better or worse, choosing to help yourself or others, choosing sides/factions, and moving your "Army" around the map to different encounters...well its all here. While I love this open book approach and multiple answer dialogue options I can definitely feel the sting of any choice I make afterwards.So onto ....the hated aspects.1-SRPG Elements ConstrainmentsThis game has control of your progression...very tightly. I'm only assuming the developers wanted control of how you progress and made this decision intentionally. Since I dont appreciate the restriction personally, I disagree with the direction almost entirely. I know building those mechanics would take a lot of hours to put in place and could have been a budget decision or they could have wanted this part to be light and not focused on heavily by the player. I just cant help but want to(ignoring the fact that i'm a veteran and have lots of things to compare this system to) considering you are fighting...well 75% of the time and you are always ALWAYS at a disadvantage. Not a single fight in this game are you evenly matched none the less above the enemy. So with no way inside their system to really cater to your playing style, I find myself getting irritated with the lack of in the system. Its presence is there, but its faint.2-No SavingEverytime I make a decision that affects something important, I prefer to be secure in my decision. I'm aware...Life doesnt have a pause button and once things are said and actions are done, the ripples around are permanent. But this isnt life, its a game. I prefer (personally) to have control over the game having control. So the lack of saving makes this...well a bit irritating. If you are similar to me then you too will be annoyed by the lack of this function. I dont play through Fallout 3 five times and make a different decision everytime I do something important. I would rather save and see what each option does. Personal way of playing and I wont claim its anything else. Its not right its not wrong, I just know I'm not the only person who does things this way with dialogue option heavy games such as this. On top of that, its an autosave system. So lets say you make a decision and you think things were going well, you win the battle, you lose it, whatever. A character you've placed an item on,used your points on to level up,etc dies and you find out through dialogue. They are GONE. Caput. Reload your previous save to try and win the battle? Nope. Reload to make a different decision in dialogue? Nope. Outcome permanent. Now that i've said that, I have to say there are some kind of ways around this. For one, it autosaves in multiple areas so if you can escape before the dialogue is done and reload there are more than one times I've used this to go back before the new autosave has saved the ripples in the ocean. Also it seems(if I recall right) when you quit abruptly(ouside of battle of course) it makes a save point at that direct point of leisure. So you can constantly quit the game and reload to beat this system. But this is....well redundant. There should simply be an intuitive save function in place to save yourself the annoyance. On a final note, its my impression that the developers wanted you to push past these losses as they are constantly letting you know you are in an ocean that you have no control over and you will gain/lose characters often due to storyline but when you lose an invested in warrior to a minor choiceits nothing more than annoying.Final Thoughts:Its a great game and one many will love. I'm very happy to play what I have of this game and I plan on finishing it all the way through. Do I plan on playing it twice or more to see the other options? No. No. and No. But I feel compelled to see the rest of the story and love looking at this game. Not to mention it actually plays flawlessly and is very well developed in all aspects minus my disagreements with the character progression system and resource management. Play it if you like games similar to FFT and Fire Emblem and make your own opinion, I strongly urge this. Thank you Stoic for your modern SRPG and I look forward to your future works and to see you mature as a developer.

content:
y 10, 2015
												A good game with excellent art and style but a basic combat system. Nice to hear the authentic accents in the few spoken lines and the music is outstanding. The gameplay consists of dialogue choices and a basic turn-based, grid combat system. As with all the best choice based dialogue games, some of the choices are the sort that cause you to sit and think for 30 minutes before selecting something you immediately regret.The combat is repetitive and once I had a go-to team I found it difficult to break from a routine (giants at the front to smash some up the baddies, archers at the back to pick off the smashed). The combat almost feels like it was added to make the game a game instead of what could have been an excellent interactive story. It beats quick time events I guess but the lack of enemy types makes everything too easy. When got bored of the combat I bumped the Difficulty setting down to Easy only to find out it was the final battle in the game. So, it was good enough for my 10 hour play time.Everything about the game feels very much like a touch screen was always in the back of the developers minds. This is not a complaint, the play style is perfected suited for dropping in and out to extend what can be a pretty bleak story. The odds are certainly against all of the characters and a string of badly handled choices can result in some miserable  setbacks.I picked the game up in the Summer sale 2014, excellent value for money. I'm on board for the planned sequels. More spoken dialogue and improved combat would build on the excellent foundation set up with The Banner Saga.

content:
ber 10, 2014
												Impressive strategy RPG with beautifully hand drawn animations and travelling sequences. Choices in encounters during caravan travels add both to the story and battle strategy, introducing a population and resource management aspect which changes depending on how the player chooses to engage enemies in group battles vs using army reserves in a cautious or direct manner. The Banner Saga has turned out to be a far more charming and deeper game than I had ever expected. More and more mechanics are introduced as one gets further into the campaign. This is one of the most satisfying SRPG / adventure experiences in a long time. I had hesitated due to the price, but for the current midweek madness sale, $10 is an amazing deal. If you were holding off for any reason, now is the time to pick up this title. I see now that even the price of $14.99 or even $20 still seems very reasonable!

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
, 2014
												Having just beaten The Banner Saga, I can now say that it will remain one of my favorites games for many years to come. The story/lore was superb, the soundtrack was fantastic ( I highly recommend getting the edition with the soundtrack), and I found myself protective of the games main characters Rook and his daughter Allete. The meat of the game revolves around balancing the level progression of your characters while also providing resources for your caravhan, which both use the same resource to manage. It can be a struggle depending on what difficulty you're playing on, but if you're just looking to enjoy the story it is very possible without sacrificing any fun. I highly recommend this game if you are a fan of turn based strategies, deep emotional stories, and worlds that are rich in lore.

content:
y 14, 2014
												Amazing art and animation. Taking inspiration from Eyvind Earle (Disney's Sleeping Beauty) gives this game a classic Disney feel. The writing is a bit slow and drawn out, borderline amateur. But overall I'm pretty happy with the game so far. The battle system is simple and well explained. It's a bit slow overall so if you're one of those "need it done now" type of people this game may not be for you. Wish there were voice acting but I shouldn't expect much from a Kickstarter game. You play multiple perspectives from the different main characters each chapter. Overall it's a very Sleeping Beauty mixed with Game of Thrones story and vibe with a heavy Viking mythology sway. Overall a pretty cool experience and one of those games you'll play and be in awe of the art direction. I hope the story pans out a little better as I progress through the story.As it stands I have NOT FINISHED the game. But from this point I'd give the game a nice clean 8/10. Mostly due to the art direction and battle system.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
, 2014
												The most remarkable aspect of this game is presentation. From the soundtrack to the art direction to the interface, everything is immaculate and elegant. Nothing feels rough around the edges or half-finished as far as those elements go. The gameplay is unique- a combination of choose-your-own-adventure style frequent decision-making, an Oregan Trail-like survival and travel element that involves some resource management, and the battle system itself which involves tactical strategy and some interesting components like individual health and defense bars to attack, and the Varl race of characters who take up a lot of unit space in battle but have high attack power. There are so many characters to choose from during battle- as many as 20 are encountered by game's end and even character usage involves some decision-making as characters only level up by not only actively participating, but getting in a number of kills.Now for some of the downsides- though there are such a plethora of options and routes to go on, nearly all lead toward the same end and plot points seem black and white in nature- you either picked the "right" answer leading to hidden items or a surplus in resources, or you picked the wrong one which can set you back in progress. But making wrong decisions matters little since the difficulty level is low until the end, and the initially interesting tactics-driven combat is actually quite simplified compared to other strategy RPGs. Aspects such as equipment management involve collecting numerous accessories and each character can hold just one. Character classes and stat allocation is similarly straightforward. On the bright side, that makes this title a great choice for those new to the genre and not very interested in micro-management. The storyline is interesting and involved, but there is not much clarification of the lore. While the character and plot development is nicely done, it can be vague with some side characters receiving barely a line of exposition. While I compared the decision-making to a choose-your-own-adventure novel, it has nowhere near the verbosity of visual novels or many story-driven RPGs. The writing is of an appreciably high standard of quality though and the lack of meandering over any particular element (whether it be storytelling or the various types of gameplay present here) keeps the game fast-paced. I achieved completion at around 10 hours and do feel there is some replay value here, but the general asking price ($24.99) is very high for this amount of content. I would suggest waiting for a sale of at least 30-50% off. The exception being if the subject matter is particularly riveting to you, in which case I'd say go ahead as it is likely to impress.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
er 8, 2014
												I wrote a bit about this game  here [hits.raygunsue.org], which I'll quote below for the super curious. Overall, I really enjoy it, but it gives you a funny feeling. Initially I felt a bit cheated by the twenty dollars it cost me, because so much of the game seemed extremely formulaic -- yet it burned through a Sunday for me when I really did have other things I needed to do. It seems like formulaic aspects of the game don't stop the choices you make from feeling important, even though you are constantly under-informed as to their consequences and nothing every seems to go right. That seems to be part of the point. It's a great game for winter, though I'd recommend having a precise time limit in mind.Here's the much longer version:Those old Hanna-Barbera cartoons used to have these funny tells. Velma Dinkley would be inspecting a book case for clues, and you could always tell, because of a marked difference between shelves, which one would have a trap door. I’m sure this was just an artifact of the animating process, such that there was a distinct difference between the background and moveable foreground items, but it also functioned brilliantly with the premise of shows like Scooby-Doo, the three-second anticipation of animation and the formula to every episode braiding together so that nothing really unexpected occurred. Dull, but delightfully so.

The Banner Saga shares some of these elements. Much of the game consists in the shift of a caravan proceeding horizontally across landscape and screen, and though there are animations, much of these are repetitive, glancing eyes and twisting hair. But though these are dull, in a sense, the effect isn’t unfascinating. The game is dull in an aesthetic way, in the way that wintry world would be, where it seemed at every point that my caravan was simply going from bad to worse circumstances, and when they would cut to those animations of the characters, glancing eyes and twisting hair, it seemed realistic, that people in a cold and godless world would address their inevitably sour options with little change in expression. Dull, like hit too much too often.

That safe feeling, in Hanna-Barbera and The Banner Saga, is tied to seeing nothing change except the foreground. Now, for the latter, this isn’t strictly true. Terrible things occur at various points in the game, directly affecting both the brave caravan and the landscape of the world around you. Yet so much of the game feels the same. You careen from danger to danger, watching food run out, watching the number of units following you ebb. Until a red pop-up tells you that two mothers are fighting over the marital prospects of their daughters, or that a varl, (a horned immortal) was found clawing himself in the woods — or, more dramatically, that someone important, to the characters and to your goals in the game, has died, or betrayed you. When things happen, they happen textually. Beyond that, the in-game visuals are limited to varieties of landscape, varieties of battlefield, and varieties of campsites. (And, as said, the occasional animated exchange, where this animation involves very little beyond glancing eyes and twisting hair and printed dialogue.) But these limitations don’t feel like laziness.

A Song of Ice and Fire has similar levels of dull-ness and bad-to-worse-ness and also occurs in a rich, historied world, where big things are happening. But, being a series of books, it happens entirely textually. And that seems important. When I played Final Fantasy 8, my actions scar the world, and I see it, in the world map or otherwise. Things change, and also you are constantly chased from bad-to-worse. Neither ASOIAF or FF8 offered me quite the same experience I’m having here, but for different reasons. Since I do not make choices in Westeros, I can empathize with the plights of the ASOIAF characters, but though I am certainly rooting for some, I am never anxious, usually simply in a state of proto-grief. Though I did make choices in FF8, there was never a sense (supported by in-game information) that this was all business as usual.

I think The Banner Saga provides a kind of game delicacy: the sense of making decisions in dreadful world, where your decisions have weight, yet so routinely lead to bad consequences, where one feels very ordinary and not up to the task, in just the way the characters do.

To get that sense, I think you need elements like formulaic visuals, but choices, too, presented textually. There’s something either very powerful or sadly impotent about one’s imaginative capabilities when reading: I rarely notice inconsistencies. Part of that might be because I’m invested too much mentally, such that I pull out everything I can to make it all work, or I’ve invested too little, such that I haven’t even really imagined things enough to notice inconsistencies.1 That a significant part of the game is textual, and that what is significant within the game occurs textually, seems important. When you pair the formulaic visuals with a rich2 imagined space, I think you get tugged in two directions. You’re anxious because of textually presented decisions, and yet you keep scrolling through the same-old-same-old. Even though there are terrible things happening in the world, the formula for game-play presented in the visuals never seems to reflect the anxious sense you get from the textual decisions, and so their weight never seems to be fully evidenced in the game play. It gives me a rainy-day feeling that literature usually lacks. “All these things need to get done!”, even as the years slip forward.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
y 22, 2014
												I'm lost at words to describe how much I thoroughly enjoyed The Banner Saga. This title has such a mesmorizing score and astonishing artwork. Let's not forget about the  characters. Combining all that with the impressively well done story leaves you with an immersion one would not expect from an adventure game.You are the leader of your clansmen and during your adventure you encounter numerious trials and tribulations, many which will leave you questioning your morale compass. To name a few: Starving strangers, backstabbers, gluttony, schemers, gender equality, racism. How will you deal with them in each encounter? How will you deal with troublemakers in your caravan? I found this to be very much like The Walking Dead mixed with Oregon/Organ Trail in terms of the choices you are make!The game eases you into the story and gameplay mechanics. The turn-based combat system is very easy to understand with a steep learning curve. Players who are familiar with tabletop, armor values, attack values, etc won't have as much trouble. The difficulty is in the risk factor. There are two values, Strength and Shield; Strength is for attack value and health while Shield is your armor value that reduces incoming Strength attacks. Despite how this all looks really simple, it's a lot more complicated. I had a very interesting time learning how to maximize the effectiveness of combat. There is also a limited resource called Will that you can exert your troops to more further or deal more damage. Do you weaken the enemy shield first before dealing a swift deathly blow or do you attack their strength and make them deal less damage in return?I am a huge fan of the story and setting. I love Norse mytho and Banner Saga has numerous hints of it as inspiration. I'm also fond of many of the characters personalities and how well detailed they are. They have layers of complexion and every single one of them have their own goals/motives/opinions; strangers can become allies, allies can become enemies. However, looking back, I wasn't able to bond with most of the characters...strange. I cannot applaud the developers enough. This here, The Banner Saga, is a work of art. I cannot sing enough praise.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
y 26, 2015
												What a great RPG game. I kind of found this game by accident while navigating through Steam and after reading a bit about it online I decided to go ahead and buy it. It was a damn good decision. It is a bit of a different RPG as for most of it you are left with managing your caravan supplies and day to day problems. The game is linear so there isn't room for you to walk around and explore things like Skyrim or any other RPG out there. The thing about The Banner Saga is it story and how you go about it. Despite being straightforward regarding where you are going you have a say on how you are going to get there. The how in question is not about which route to take physically but rather emtionally and morally. As you travel with your caravan and your supplies dwindle should you threaten a farmer in order to obtain food? Or would you rather negotiate with him?  When a baby is born in your caravan do you stop and celebrate given people have been dying left and right? Or do you say, nope we don't have the resources to cheer, let's carry on? Another thing that really hooks you are the characters. Despite being rather short the game makes you care about each and everyone of the main chars. The problem with this is that no character is exempt from being killed during the game, and it ends up to you to choose weather to add a character to the lineup and potentially risk his/her death. At the end of the game, you end up feeling quite pleased of having survived the ride and also a bit depressed for all the bad things that happened to your party and caravan along the way. For me it was a sad thing to have killed Alette, the main character's daughter, at the final battle as she was my favorite character. Her funeral, in viking manner where her body is placed in a burning ship and sent along the river, was one of the most emotional moments in gaming for me.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
ry 14, 2015
												Banner Saga is a study in videogames as a storytelling medium. The score, the sounds, the visual style, and the writing all work together beautifully to tell the story of a merciless world falling apart. It's tense and you're always on the verge of annihilation, and the music alone could tell you so. It's gritty, and the crunches of axes breaking armor and the grunts and moans of the injured make you feel it. People are fragile and the perpetual march is exhausting, and the heavy shambling motions of bodies shows you so.  As the leader, you constantly have to arbitrate the problems of your followers, keep them optimistic, keep them fed, and keep them alive while a continent of panicking and desperate people is being overrun.  Everything harmoniously comes together to weave an atmosphere where feelings of dread and anxiety are constant. Your choice isn't whether or not people die, it's who dies now so that fewer will die later.  In every artistic regard this game is an achievement.Unfortunately it's not for everyone, though. Its roots are in the artistry, not the gameplay--people have some valid complaints about that. Only some. I didn't dislike the gameplay at all, but I was very wrapped up in every other part of the game. Play it for the experience.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
ry 15, 2015
												As a fan of turn based strategy games I can't say that The Banner Saga is a great game. The strategic part is very basic and isn't more complex than a game of checkers. Also the user interface is really abysmal, the worst I've ever seen in a strategic game. For example you can't inspect your team members attributes and abilities when choosing who to bring in battle. While in battle the interface isn't better and choosing the action to perform feels very cheap. Abilities are described "with text" like a game from 20 years ago, no icons and no visual aids. Very very basic.Despite all this I still recommend the game; why? Because the story is tragic and mature like it rarely happens in games lately. It is really up to Norse Myths standards... The music is a masterpiece that is alone worth the price of the game and the experience, as whole, feels like a work of love from its developers. So even if I can't fully recommend it as a game I still recommend it without hesitation as a work of "art".

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
y 22, 2014
												I'm lost at words to describe how much I thoroughly enjoyed The Banner Saga. This title has such a mesmorizing score and astonishing artwork. Let's not forget about the  characters. Combining all that with the impressively well done story leaves you with an immersion one would not expect from an adventure game.You are the leader of your clansmen and during your adventure you encounter numerious trials and tribulations, many which will leave you questioning your morale compass. To name a few: Starving strangers, backstabbers, gluttony, schemers, gender equality, racism. How will you deal with them in each encounter? How will you deal with troublemakers in your caravan? I found this to be very much like The Walking Dead mixed with Oregon/Organ Trail in terms of the choices you are make!The game eases you into the story and gameplay mechanics. The turn-based combat system is very easy to understand with a steep learning curve. Players who are familiar with tabletop, armor values, attack values, etc won't have as much trouble. The difficulty is in the risk factor. There are two values, Strength and Shield; Strength is for attack value and health while Shield is your armor value that reduces incoming Strength attacks. Despite how this all looks really simple, it's a lot more complicated. I had a very interesting time learning how to maximize the effectiveness of combat. There is also a limited resource called Will that you can exert your troops to more further or deal more damage. Do you weaken the enemy shield first before dealing a swift deathly blow or do you attack their strength and make them deal less damage in return?I am a huge fan of the story and setting. I love Norse mytho and Banner Saga has numerous hints of it as inspiration. I'm also fond of many of the characters personalities and how well detailed they are. They have layers of complexion and every single one of them have their own goals/motives/opinions; strangers can become allies, allies can become enemies. However, looking back, I wasn't able to bond with most of the characters...strange. I cannot applaud the developers enough. This here, The Banner Saga, is a work of art. I cannot sing enough praise.

												Impressive strategy RPG with beautifully hand drawn animations and travelling sequences. Choices in encounters during caravan travels add both to the story and battle strategy, introducing a population and resource management aspect which changes depending on how the player chooses to engage enemies in group battles vs using army reserves in a cautious or direct manner. The Banner Saga has turned out to be a far more charming and deeper game than I had ever expected. More and more mechanics are introduced as one gets further into the campaign. This is one of the most satisfying SRPG / adventure experiences in a long time. I had hesitated due to the price, but for the current midweek madness sale, $10 is an amazing deal. If you were holding off for any reason, now is the time to pick up this title. I see now that even the price of $14.99 or even $20 still seems very reasonable!

content:
y 10, 2015
												A good game with excellent art and style but a basic combat system. Nice to hear the authentic accents in the few spoken lines and the music is outstanding. The gameplay consists of dialogue choices and a basic turn-based, grid combat system. As with all the best choice based dialogue games, some of the choices are the sort that cause you to sit and think for 30 minutes before selecting something you immediately regret.The combat is repetitive and once I had a go-to team I found it difficult to break from a routine (giants at the front to smash some up the baddies, archers at the back to pick off the smashed). The combat almost feels like it was added to make the game a game instead of what could have been an excellent interactive story. It beats quick time events I guess but the lack of enemy types makes everything too easy. When got bored of the combat I bumped the Difficulty setting down to Easy only to find out it was the final battle in the game. So, it was good enough for my 10 hour play time.Everything about the game feels very much like a touch screen was always in the back of the developers minds. This is not a complaint, the play style is perfected suited for dropping in and out to extend what can be a pretty bleak story. The odds are certainly against all of the characters and a string of badly handled choices can result in some miserable  setbacks.I picked the game up in the Summer sale 2014, excellent value for money. I'm on board for the planned sequels. More spoken dialogue and improved combat would build on the excellent foundation set up with The Banner Saga.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
er 30, 2015
												Three things make The Banner Saga excellent:First, the setting is well done.  The plot is interesting even if, in a general sense, it is unoriginal.  It really shines in the details and nuances (especially how the plot and characters interact) and the feeling of desperation and struggle really comes through as the game progresses.  The music is exceptional.  It's epic when it needs to be without being over the top and subtle when it needs to be without being unnoticeable.  The visuals and sound effects are also solid, and I especially enjoyed the animation style that Stoic used for this game.Second, the choices.  Your choices really drive this game in a way I haven't seen in many others.  Sure you have games where you're faced with a choice that may have implications later, but they're usually easy choices that are morally unambiguous and where the repercussions easy to predict.  In the Banner Saga choices are not so easy.  Choices that seem to be clear and easily made result in unexpected consequences sometimes immediately, sometimes not until much later in the game.  Other choices are just difficult.  The consequences of your choices can be serious as well.  For example, one plot choice I made early in the game resulted in the death of two of my characters much later in the game.  There's also the constant choice of what to do with your primary resource in the game.  It's very limited and you have to decide if you are going to use it to make your characters more powerful or make sure your party can eat for another few days.  You'll be sitting there, sometimes agonizing over your choices and wishing the game were more obvious but loving the fact that it isn't.Finally, the combat.  I like the system a lot.  If you've played turn-based, party-focused combat games before, the basic mechanics are essentially the same.  But there's enough thrown in there to change how you fight and make things interesting.  For example, a unit's health and damage potential are linked (same stat) so the more a character is wounded the less damage that character can do to another character's health.  This alone is an interesting element but you also have another factor with armor mitigating damage to the point where, if a character's armor is high enough, you may not be able to damage that character at all.  This forces you to figure out if it's better to inflict less health damage on an enemy, making him weaker but keeping him in the fight, or if it's better to risk that same enemy being able to do higher damage to your party while you soften him up for a death blow.  Add to that special abilities that are varied and can take some clever playing to set up for maximum effectiveness and you have a combat system that is both consistent enough to get the hang of and become proficient at, but also varied enough to keep things interesting.But there is a bit of bad with the good:First, the game is pretty short.  I was actually surprised when I beat it, and for $20 I think this game could have included a bit more content.  I didn't time myself but it probably took me between 12 and 15 hours to beat the game.  There's some replayability with the fact that there are so many choices to be made and you could spend hours exploring them all but, being so plot-driven, once you've experienced the plot, repeated playthroughs become more mechanical than anything else.Second, this game could have benefitted greatly from a skirmish mode.  There is something of a skirmish mode with the Training Tent, but the only variables you control there are the party you bring and this is limited by where you are in the game, who you have in your party, what their levels are, and what items you've obtained.  A separate skirmish mode where you could set up your own custom battles would have been perfect and enhanced the replayability of the game by giving the player the opportunity to explore all the aspects of the combat system they're interested in, or just hop in and smash some skulls for fun.All in all, I really enjoyed this game and am excited for the sequel.  If an excellent setting and interesting plot are your thing, this game has them.  If you're interested in a game where your choices can have a serious impact on how your game plays, this game does that.  If you're even just into turn-based combat RPGs, this is one worthy of your time.

												First of all, this is such a beautiful game. The art direction is fantastic and very memorable. I have played many games where developers claim that 'your decisions affect the overall game'. This is a very bold statement and most games never truly live up to it. The Banner Saga more than lives up to this statement. The story is brutal and the gameplay can be unforgiving (in a good way), which only adds to its charm. In a time where developers will often play it safe and produce what is sure to sell, The Banner Saga is an absolute breath of fresh air. What I found most interesting about this game was the world, lore and its characters. It's deep and very well structured. It truly feels like an epic journey and when tragedy does strike it's often a very powerful moment. I can't wait to experience more games within this saga. 100% recommended.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
6, 2016
												(Disclaimer: The following review was done before playing the sequel(s) and is exclusively pertinent to it.)Banner Saga is the first chapter in a series that weaves nordic mythology and aesthetic with an interesting unique fantasy world that is quite apocalyptic in tone. It mixes tactical RPG elements with a survival "on-rails" traveling mechanic (the term "viking orion trail" describes it quite well), both dictated ultimately by a visual novel "choice-based" gameplay structure.This game's strongest qualities are by far its brilliantly crafted artistic elements: Story, graphics and music. The graphics are wonderful and seeing traditional hand-drawn 2d animation in a world where 3d animation is the norm is refreshing. The backgrounds are inspired by artist Eyvind Earle (they even named a character after him) and are quite breathtaking. The music sounds quite authentic in its attempts to complement its theme, as it mixes elements of traditional nordic folk music (with singing), and is very well composed and was recorded in an actual orchestra which brings it to a whole new level. The story is quite interesting and in parts quite brutal. The worldbuilding is well done and pulls you in quite intensely - though it feels a bit narrow in its scope, lacking a bit of cultural and political diversity at times. As for the plot, there are definately some "game of thronesy" ruthlessness (minus the outward adult elements to it), feeling like you're never really safe and anything can happen - except perhaps for some degree of "plot armor" that perhaps can't be avoided when you're writing a protagonist-driven narrative.Now for the gameplay, which is where the real faults of this game unfortunately lie:As I said before there are three elements that compose this game: A tactical RPG element that takes place in battles, a on-rails Orion Trail style travelling mechanic which takes place when going from one place to another, and a visual novel, "choose-your-adventure book" type of gameplay where the story and dialogue is presented to you and you have to make decisions to lead the game foward, decisions which can prove fortuitous or give you trouble. The problem and the biggest flaw of this game is the fact that it pretends that it is not linear. It constantly throws you game elements that tease you into a false sense of freedom - such as the battle system, which is the only part where the "RPG" element really takes place - like for example the map system, which shows you a richly detailed world with many places to go, but never giving you the choice to actively opt to travel to any of those places, but instead claustrophobically forcing you to follow a set trail from which you can never stray off (and from which you can't even go back - once you're going foward, there is no stopping). The resource system is quite simplistic, and the game "money" is only acquired in battle and is used for everything, including leveling up your characters. And to make it worse, it's in quite short supply, essencially robbing you with the pleasure of making your characters stronger in case you don't want to, you know, starve to death. This is where the Viking Trail element comes in - yes, you need food to feed your caravan. And not only it's difficult to find supplies, but you also lose them very easily, especially due to events that happen over which you have no control.The game also doesn't make clear what the advantage of having a large caravan even is.Now I have only played this game once, so I only know the extent to which choices matters from other people talking about it, but as far as I know, a lot of the choices don't actually change the story very significantly. Which can be kind of dishonest as it sabotages the feeling you get when first playing the game of you having crafted your own story.All in all, the game feels way too much like a book. A book where you sometimes play "chess" against, and a very good one at that, but still a book. But anyway, I really enjoyed playing it, and I appreciate the effort that went into it, so I'm giving it a positive review. But it could certainly be more of a "game", or at least be more honest about how much it isn't.

												TLDR: Banner Saga left me with an intense hunger for more, which is so much worse as the game is so awesome!If you like the Fire Emblem series, consider playing this game. It has some interesting takes on the tactical RPG genre, an awesome art style with beutiful scenery and rich characters. I found the story interesting and was especially impressed by the hardship and difficult choices of a refugee story arc. I was, however, also a little frustrated. The skill caps of your heros are very low, and I feel the leveling/customization choices  are quite limited. At least you get a lot of heros to try out but you don't get enough time and resources to explore them all very well. I also did not like that the narrative unnecessarily imposes that you play a certain character. Especially in a part, where Alette, a relatable girl, could easily be the main character you are forced into the role of Rook, her father, and have to decide her fate with some patronizing choices. And then the story ends very abruptly.

content:

												The Banner Saga is an extraordinary game. Starting with the obvious, the landscapes and soundtrack are both breathtaking and plain epic. But what what really reeled me in, even more than the wonderful and immersive atmosphere, is the storyline. Twisted, and relying so very much on the player's choices. You often don't know where you're going, what to decide, whom you should trust or not, and must rely on your own judgement (often wrong !) and guts to advance. It is such a pleasure to feel like you're are actually choosing, or creating your own path rather than following the same patterns as always ; and it's not so often that a game really makes you think twice about a choice that will (maybe) haunt you until the end... The Banner Saga is really a refreshing creation, dark indeed, but beautiful nonetheless, and takes you in without mercy. I just finished it, and already want to discover all the other paths that lie ahead... I recommend it whole-heartedly !

												A true testament to the idea that games don't have to have amazing 3d graphics to be captivating visually. The Banner Saga has some of the most beautiful art I have ever seen in a video game, and with a fantastic soundtrack (which I can't get enough of), it's a great accomplishment. But that's not all at what this game excels, because it's RPG/tactic combat and difficult choices to make, are also something I strongly praise. However, even with such a great formula, I can't overlook the fact, that it feels rushed and incomplete. There are some rare moments of voice acted animated scenes, but only in the beginning, and are nowhere to be found even near the end of the game. Also in some parts of the game you just know that things were suppose to be much bigger, but due to some kind of constrains, they ended up as they are. Nonetheless, I enjoyed myself for the (too) short time I played The Banner Saga. I just hope the next installments are more complete products.

												Highly recommended. Great strategy game with an intriguing story. Been playing this with my non-gamer wife watching and helping me make the story decisions while I handle combat for the most part. 18 hours in  she's  telling me how to spec out the party and what to do each turn. Easy to get into but suprisingly deep while offering a lot of ambiguous choices with unforseeable consequences which can dramatically impact both the story and mechanical character progression/combat.Its not a game you can ace. It's a game where you have to live with the consequences of your choices, whatever they may be, and there isn't always a clear right or wrong decision for every situation.Did I mention it's gorgeous and the music is spectacular? Worth noting that it works well as a mouse-only game, making it a turn based strategy game that plays well on the TV from the couch. Most enjoyable turn-based strategy RPG I've played in a long time.

												Check out our full review at VGBlogger.com: http://www.vgblogger.com/discussion-review-the-banner-saga/25152/Parts of The Banner Saga feel incomplete or less fleshed out than they could have been, and in some cases outright and purposefully unforgiving in order to match the storyline's harsh tone and subject matter. But taken as a whole the experience is deeply fulfilling, thanks to well developed characters that you will actually care about and want to get to know, a narrative and game world of epic scope, and a tactically rich turn-based battle system that puts some smart twists on tradition. And what more can I say about the game's stunning artistry? Some of the cutscene portraits and landscape shots made me wish I could print them out and frame to hang on my wall, instead of only being able to capture them as screenshots to use for desktop wallpapers. If Disney or Rankin/Bass ever made a mature cel-animated movie about Vikings, it would probably look a whole lot like The Banner Saga.

content:
27, 2014
												After completing this game once here's the best way to describe it:Breathtaking.Now I don't mean that in a lame metaphorical way specifically, but suffice it to say that there will be times where you will be caught completely off guard by the plot, and the fact that you had direct influence on it. I immediately started playing again, not for the sake of acheivements or even getting a "best ending" but just wanting to do things a little differently.I'm not really a connoiseur when it comes to music, but unlike other games I never listened to my own music on top of the game's.Visually this game is amazing. Boiled down, yea its a bunch of simply cycling illustrations, but those illustrations are brilliantly done, and never make you feel like you're watching some dumb gif loop. In line with that it is one of the only games I can play on my laptop's fan run like a jet engine, which is to say, it is in no way demanding for any computer to run.That said, assuming that the place where my first game ended is in fact the ending of the game, I think the loose ends did catch my attention. That didn't at all take away from the overall experience, and if anything it makes me think that they will (hopefully) be releasing a sequel, what with the girth of lore that was given to the game. Over your travels within the game you travel not even a fifth of the presented world, but it never feels like you're missing anuything. In actuality it just made me wish I could go farther, which is probably the right way for a game to make you feel.The combat is fantastic. I was amazed and enthralled with Factions, and the minor tweaks that were made to pre and during combat gameplay was done with this game in mind, not bending to any sort of predesigned border. Such a thrilling experience during every battle.A small thing that I really did appreciate was that RNG was in the hands of the player. Only by equipping certain items did RNG ever come into play, which is something I wish a lot of Tactical Strategy RPGs (or what have you) would do as well.TL;DR,A game with the smallest of blemishes that left me wanting more, 9.5/10

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
4, 2014
												Hello,I'm going to start off by saying that this is a beautiful game. By beautiful I mean soundtrack, artwork and story. It's really enjoyable and definitely worth playing. It has a very... "Authentic" feeling to it.Pros:Artwork - The artwork is beautifully drawn and everything is nicely animated. Even though a bit simple at times, even the simplicity of it all seems to blend in perfectly with everything.Music - The soundtrack is nice and gives off an appropriate vibe considering the setting, but it's not incredible. It's nice, really, but it could have been a bit more diverse.Story & Character development - The story and character development are amazing. Even though they have small flaws, everything seems somehow inevitable and most of the time you are basically doing everything to make the best out of an impossible situation. That's the real struggle. Doing the best you can - no matter how bad it is.The characters are nicely designed and some of them actually evolve in unexpected ways, even if they do scream cliché at times.Skills and attributes - These go hand to hand with their usability in combat (which I will explain below) and how much you really need to think about when you upgrade them.Combat - I assume that we've all seen this type of combat by now and its basics should come as no surprise to anyone. I like the general combat style, but what I love about it are some small touches that make it... Unique. Crippling the armour of an enemy is generally optional in games, but not here. No way. If you want to actually have a chance at slaying Dredge, then you really need to buff up your armor breaking. Also damaging an opponent will not only hurt them physically and take down their hp, but will also reduce the damage they do.I like the fact that the game forces you to weigh your decisions carefully, most of the time having to choose either damaging an opponent with a small burst for the moment or simply working your way until being able to constantly damage them for higher values.Cons:Voice acting - Although sometimes done well, a large part of the voice acting in the game could do with improving. Of course, it's understandable seeing how the actors were chosen and the fact that Stoic didn't exactly have an immense budget for this project.Decisions - This is the type of game which is, for the most part, story-driven. Generally the types of fans that play this type of game are the ones that expect their role and their decisions in the to be important. It is exactly the type of game from which fans expect every decision to be important and to have significant consequences. Don't get me wrong, they're important, obviously, but I wish that some of the decisions that ulteriorly end up with the same result to have some more depth to them. The fact that quite often anything you choose to do will lead you through the same events is not what bothers me. What bothers me is that the game is quite transparent about that and lets it off quite easily.Character leveling - I really think that they should have sticked to the standard form of leveling (Everyone who's still standing at the end of the fight will get exp), buuut they didn't. Instead you gain exp for dealing the killing blow on enemies. Normally that wouldn't be so bad, but it's just so much easier for some characters to get the kil than others, that it basically makes the process of leveling certain classes very, very difficult. There's always that one big guy, with the two-hander that comes in and beats the crap out of everything that's still standing.Equipment - Well, there's really not much I can say about the equipemnt section because it didn't actually stand out. I expected equipmented rooted into the lore of the game that can help an immense deal, but I actually got a lot of items which could situationally help... Somtimes. Some items are good, sure, but not really that much. The difference they make isn't all that noticeable if you spend your points properly.Conclusion:This is a great game, definitely worth buying if you enjoy your good ol' tacitacal turn-based. But it's more than that. It's actually a great buy if you simply enjoy a good story. Combat isn't all that difficult and it's easy to get into, even if it does, at times, get a bit tiring (I'm talking about you, people who want to try out every possible path and never want any characters to get knocked out.

content:
7, 2015
												I absolutely loved this game, so simple and kind of reminds me of Hearthstone in the way that the Health/Armour works, although subtle differences.The artwork is pretty good although sometimes got a bit repetitive with all the snow, it made you unable to see most of the background other than the main path however when there was less snow it was beautiful atmosphere. Overall I love the cartoon feel to it.Enough of the graphics. The main thing I love about this game is the fact that the decisions you make, actually do have an effect. Not only that but it makes you think about what you want to say, Do you need another character? Do you need more suplies? What one should I choose to keep my character alive? Should I take a risk?All these questions I was asking myself as I progressed.However sometimes I felt that some decisions made no sense to me - personally - and that some were harsh as it sometimes causes some of the characters to die, it obviously has no effect on the story but it is annoying as you may have levelled that character to a high level and spent your XP points on him and then he is gone, seems like a waste.I also dislike the fact that one group of characters you get to play with are not as powerful as some of the other groups and I felt like some characters I was able to level up easier as they did more base damage, the "archer" type felt fairly useless in most circumstances as the space the "Dredge" can move is so great compared to the range of the arrows, it felt like a wasted character to me, they have low armour and low strength and it just did not gel with my preferred playstyle and also I felt like the Varl were FAR superior to the humans.However the storyline was interesting although fairly short, it also had me addicted for the 5-10 hours it lasted and I am on my second playthrough on a harder difficulty and choosing different options. It has replayability in that way.The final boss fight is extremely challenging and I enjoyed it thoroughly, with many retries, and many rages.Amazing animations in combat and although the Voice acting was scarce, it was effective when used. It could have been used more and there is A HELL OF A LOT OF READING, which I am fine with but you may not be. When speaking to people, it sometimes felt like it was drawn out and too much text but I liked it nonetheless. Requires patience.I would advise you to pick this game up, mainly if it is on sale. 100% worth $15 and less but I picked it up for $5 I think.An amazing game overall and I loved it so much while it lasted.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
ry 3, 2014
												Highly recommend this game for fans of tactical RPGs, or turn-based RPG combat in general. It makes some questionable design decisions at various points, but is well worth every cent of the asking price. (If you pick it up later on during a Steam sale, congratulations, you're winning.)Selling points: this is possibly amongst the most beautiful games I have ever played. Not in terms of "graphical fidelity," of course, but the cel-shaded art style is extremely well-done all the way through and quite captivating. I would happily take games in this style over mainstream AAA titles living in the uncanny valley over and over again. My only complaint in this area is the extremely limited character animation during "cutscene" conversations; what is there simply serves to highlight how little there is. I probably wouldn't even have noticed if not for the few efforts they made on this front. (A very, VERY minor complaint, since the game is not relying on FMV-style, and even in still shots, the artwork is simply gorgeous)The tactical combat is engaging, and the mechanic which links a character's health to his damage output makes an otherwise simplistic system compelling (do I do limited damage against this enemy to lower the danger they bring, or reduce his armor to make my next turn that much more effective while risking him bringing the hurt in the interim?) and makes level-up decisions on characters agonizing. I went the route of "specializing" each character I used frequently, resulting in characters of similar class and starting stat reaching the end-game with vastly different skill sets (i.e. of the two archers I used every opportunity, one was the absolute best at knocking enemy armor out of the picture, while the other was a damage-and-willpower fiend who had my highest kill count by the last fight). Also, while I'm not huge on harping for realism in games, it has always somewhat annoyed me that characters with 1HP out of their 1,000 maximum were just as potent as at full health, and this is a nice way of remedying that.The story arc is compelling and kept me interested the whole way through without relying on many overdone tropes and archetypes, taking place in a very interesting setting I would happily p[ay to see more of. There is also quite a bit of background lore and information made easily accessible without forcing it to the forefront through excessive exposition, leaving its perusal to those willing to spend the time to enjoy it and letting those less interested mostly ignore it without detracting from the direct experience.The Renown system, which irritated me a great deal, but in a good way (as odd as that sounds). EVERYTHING in this game - level-ups, food for your tribe, items to supplement your heroes - is purchased with renown, which you gain from victory in battle as well as certain C&C moments in between. While it can be frustrating at times, after beating the game, I view it in a wholly positive light - rather than making something like EXP and Gold to be used for two separate purposes, incorporating both resource pools into one base stat increases the strategic element, and makes every expenditure that much more risky and demanding. I entered the final battle with three fully-leveled characters, and two weaker ones, simply because I had spent the renown necessary to do so along the way to ensure nobody in my caravan starved to death along the way. (Which can also say a lot about you as a person, I suppose, in terms of how you choose to spend it) At times, I would have preferred separate pools for the various resources, but only because it would have made my inherent min-maxing tendencies easier to oblige, and I cannot legitimately call out a design decision that increases complexity and the importance of a player's strategic choice.Detriments: the touted choice & consequence mechanic, while always nice to see, seems to mostly amount to extremely random and jarring consequences; each major decision seems to have one "correct" option which yields a positive outcome, and the negative consequences of "incorrect" decisions are never forewarned adequately, resulting in major impact up to and including losing substantial characters with absolutely no warning (on courses of action they themself recommend, even). Think the Witcher in terms of its unforseeability, but without the time delay or overall neutral tone which was par for the course in that game. (To be fair, there were a couple consequences - one VERY major one - which took half the game to  conclude and did have ample but not flagrant warning, so the game did this quite well in some instances, but failed in others)The combat never changes or develops in a significant way after the first battle outside of levelled-up abilities and new character classes with different special skills opening up different strategic options. What you see in the first battle is largely what you're going to get.In the combat mechanics, again, the game seems to settle in the middle; the endgame battles (especially the final boss) had me biting nails and languishing over every turn, and the beginning was not far removed, but I had comfortably established a routine throughout the middle half of the game which pretty much ensured I'd win any given battle ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥d-drunk with minimal unit injury in the process. A more level experience would be nice.A mechanic I rather like (linking health and damage output to the same attribute) has its flaw; in many situations, it is often tactically better to leave an enemy unit on the battlefield at very low HP rather than killing them outright. Due to the mechanic Il ike, their damage potential is next to nothing, but this goes against general gaming instinct and raises concerns in compliance with the point below...MIXED FEELINGS: the way the turn-based system is executed. Instead of some stat which addresses/influences initiative, the game will always go YOUR SIDE-ENEMY SIDE-YOUR SIDE-ENEMY SIDE until only one unit remains on either, at which point one side will execute all of its turns and then the other proceeds. On one hand, I like this to an extent, because it makes battles lopsided in terms of numbers not unwinnable; on the other hand, I think it's fairly backward in terms of a good mechanic; if it were kept the same throuh the last round, it would give that moment of despair when you haver one unit left against four an air of possibility, thinking if you execute well enough you can pull this situation out of the fire (or, conversely, keep you thinking your moves over in the last moments of a fight, as an enemy acting that quickly could turn your 4-1 advantage into a one-on-one exchange if you ♥♥♥♥ it up badly enough). While I do like the mechanic as a whole as opposed to the general turn-based style, it loses its punch with that particular element making the last few turns of any given fight a foregone conclusion when it could have served to bring each and every one down to the wire.ALL IN ALL: a very, very good game. I didn't catch this game's Kickstarter in time to contribute, but most likely would have, and do not at all regret spending full price for the experience once it released. I'm hoping it does well enough that multiple follow-ups/sequels are developed, so long as they equal or improve on the quality of the original. If you enjoy slower-paced games with combat more tactical and mindful than visceral and egoistic, this is a no-brain purchase that I wholeheartedly recommend. If Call of Duty is your favorite game series... 1. this is probably not for you; 2. please die as painfully as possible in a fire as soon as possible so as to possibly rectify the damage you have already done to the industry as a whole.

content:
14, 2015
												This is a very hesitant thumbs up. See, what this page kinda neglects to mention is this is part one of a planned trilogy. I mean, I don't think I can verbally describe to you the look of "what?" on my face when the credits rolled just after what felt like the end of the first act. And while I don't generally mind multi-part stories, I think each game should at least have a satisfying self-contained story that ties in with the larger story. One series I like to point to on that is Harry Potter. Each book in that series has a self-contained story, but they also all tie in to the series-long story. This game... there's not much in the way of resolution by the end is what I'm saying. I guess in some ways that's a good thing, since if the game were much longer it would start to drag a bit, but... I just wish I'd known.Other than that, it's got a unique story, an interesting world, a unique visual style, the combat is decent (albeit a bit repetitive after a while), and I do genuinely think it's a good game; it just isn't a finished story.

												Only negative aspect i found in this marvellous game: it's lenght. Really way too short for such beatiful, well narrated story with such stunning visuals and sounds. Every single choice you make changes something, even if little; and there is so much to choose. The battles are hard and some tactics is needed. Enemies are evil ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥s that will ravage you. And if you lose the battle, the story will go on...unless you want to retry the whole chapter again. Your people will die if you choose to fight an hard battle, and so they'll die if your supplies aren't enough or simply you make bad decisions when out in the wild. They will either respect you if you prove to be a valorous leader, or pity and despise you if you only think about yourself. And this changes everything about how the story goes on.Harsh environment for a strong story, with quality narration and a mature theme. 7/10 for me, the 8-9 hours lenght really killed it. For such a masterpiece i expected like 20-30 gameplay hours atleast.

content:
y 16, 2014
												Freaking loved this game. (And who doesn't love vikings?)It has a great story and quite an unique art style. People tend to forget how immersive animation can be in both video games and movies/series, I mean.. How often do you see an animated game these days? While you are travelling the land with your caravan you'll never get bored of the background.. it so addicting to watch at, same goes for your caraven which increases in size in time.. it is kind of satisfying seeing all those people march with you upfront.The music is incredible nicely song and again.. immersive, I did notice a lack off of it while travelling with the caravan sometimes though. But beautiful nonetheless it grabs all the dangerous and emotional moments.Choices are rather important in the story.. If you make a certain choice one of your hero characters can suddenly betray you or your army gets sick by picking fruit from certain trees. Also don't let too many people join your caravan no matter how nice it might seem. (You will run out of supplies and most of them will starve to death!)The combat gameplay itself isn't that impressive but.. It's fun and can be very difficult (depening on your difficulty ofcourse).I would certainly recommend this game to those who love good story telling, characters and immersion.

content:
ry 22, 2014
												This game is essentially The Oregon Trail, but with a Nordic fantasy theme and a rudimentary turn-based combat system akin to Final Fantasy Tactics or X-Com (but with substantially less depth). The art style is refreshing, and the lovingly crafted world is enjoyable to immerse in for a while. Unfortunately, it is a very short while; most players will find themselves wanting more content after the final battle. Buy the game if it is on sale for less than $20 and I suspect you will feel rewarded by the purchase. In my opinion, the $25 price point is just a bit too high for the amount of gameplay you get.I sincerely hope that a sequel is in the works; one with a hundred hours of gameplay and a more robust combat system. This is a world I'd like to inhabit again.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
y 17, 2014
												Through its amazingly beautiful artworks, The Banner Saga unfolds its story before your eyes like a good book: It doesn't explain you everything firsthand, or spoil its world with "explanations for dummies" of why this story and where is what. No, it treats you as an intelligent reader (rather, gamer) and only leads you by hints, letting your imagination to fill the gaps between the narrative, like in a proper novel. Although you are not quite sure where the story is going, you know it's epic, desperate, and at the same time, contains enough rays of hope that let you long for your characters to reach peace and a better day. True, from a pure gaming perspective, although clever, its mechanics stay very simple, and could be seen as repetitive. But you don't want to win every battle out of cleverness, to "beat the game". You want to win them so that maybe, hopefully, this will save more of your clansmen, fighters and varls. Because the story infuses you with empathy for its likeable and complex characters, offers you few but tough choices, you end up really carring for them, not because you have level them up, but because of who they are: Rook, Alette, Iver, and all the others, struggling to survive, being doubtfull about their (yours !) decisions, hoping they will reach a happy ending.The Banner Saga is quite a unique game, because it manages something very hard to reach with this media: It conveys emotions.I can understand it's not a journey for everyone, but it definitely transported me...

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
27, 2014
												After completing this game once here's the best way to describe it:Breathtaking.Now I don't mean that in a lame metaphorical way specifically, but suffice it to say that there will be times where you will be caught completely off guard by the plot, and the fact that you had direct influence on it. I immediately started playing again, not for the sake of acheivements or even getting a "best ending" but just wanting to do things a little differently.I'm not really a connoiseur when it comes to music, but unlike other games I never listened to my own music on top of the game's.Visually this game is amazing. Boiled down, yea its a bunch of simply cycling illustrations, but those illustrations are brilliantly done, and never make you feel like you're watching some dumb gif loop. In line with that it is one of the only games I can play on my laptop's fan run like a jet engine, which is to say, it is in no way demanding for any computer to run.That said, assuming that the place where my first game ended is in fact the ending of the game, I think the loose ends did catch my attention. That didn't at all take away from the overall experience, and if anything it makes me think that they will (hopefully) be releasing a sequel, what with the girth of lore that was given to the game. Over your travels within the game you travel not even a fifth of the presented world, but it never feels like you're missing anuything. In actuality it just made me wish I could go farther, which is probably the right way for a game to make you feel.The combat is fantastic. I was amazed and enthralled with Factions, and the minor tweaks that were made to pre and during combat gameplay was done with this game in mind, not bending to any sort of predesigned border. Such a thrilling experience during every battle.A small thing that I really did appreciate was that RNG was in the hands of the player. Only by equipping certain items did RNG ever come into play, which is something I wish a lot of Tactical Strategy RPGs (or what have you) would do as well.TL;DR,A game with the smallest of blemishes that left me wanting more, 9.5/10

content:
y 20, 2014
												Where do I start with this game. Well...it's amazing.The art and animation are beautiful, story is book worthy, and this is one of the rare games I've played where choices actually matter. I think of this as part Fire Emblem and part Oregon Trail. Fighting is turn based and requires a good deal of strategy as when to take off enemy armor or go straight for their health as well when to use your characters abilities. In the overworld you need to make sure you have enough supplies to get you from city to city and along the way events will happen from thieves stealing supplies to possible permanent character death. The same points you use to buy supplies are used to upgrade you heroes. Do you use the points to make your fighters better or do you buy supplies so that you can get to the next city? I had moments while playing where I felt acutal despair as I watched my supplies run dry hoping that maybe I could find some more supplies from an event and cursing myself for using to many points to upgrade units.Did I mention the art? Oh I did...WELL IT'S FREAKING GREAT!Though I only saw one animated cutscene in the game just watching your caravan walk across the plains and seeing beautiful mountains at your back. The God Stones with their elaborate designs that also give you a little insight to the lore of the world. The in-fight animations are also very good and I think there's something really cool about the way the magic looks in the game. I think this game was worth shelling out $25 but hey that's just me. With all of the choices you can make in the game I'm very willing to do a second playthrough on a harder difficulty.

												Raise your banners it's the saga... The Banner Saga.This game... There aren't a lot of fantasy settings that really get me, but this one was one of the few. content:
y 16, 2014
												Amazing game. It's like a cross between a turn-based tactical RPG like Final Fantasy Tactics or Shining Force, and King of the Dragon Pass. Basically, there's quite a bit of combat (which would be the FF Tactics bit), but between them you have a ton of story-based and random events that requite you to make a ton of (at times really, really tough) choices. The actual story is very good, although it's rather bleak (which is a perfect fit for the Viking setting, of course).Add to that a suberb art design, composed of breathtaking traditional 2D art like I've never seen before in a computer game; and a fantastic soundtrack, and you've got yourself a truly amazing game. It's not flawless, though: while some of those flaws (like lack of full voice acting) are completely understandable, given Stoic's small size, others (like the lack of subtitles, or being forced to replay the last five hours of gameplay due to some decision you took waaaay back that now means game over for you) are not. But even with these flaws the game is still a gem, totally worth the two years Stoic took to develop it since the game's Kickstarter campaign was funded in 2012.

content:
ber 11, 2014
												The Banner Saga is an excellent turn-based RPG, where decisions you make affect the outcome of the story and changes the lives of the games characters.  The story is engrossing and revolves around a march to save your kinsmen from danger.  You lean to care about the people in your caravan, which make some of the decisions you have to make very difficult.  Although, this also gives the game a lot of replay value, as you strive to make better decisions, and protect more people in your caravan.  Decisions are more than just choosing when to fight, or dialogue choices; when it comes down to it the entire game is a decision of how best to spend your resources.  Do you buy supplies for your caravan to help you get to the next area? OR upgrade your combat team? Or buy items to have your combat team? They each use the same resource, so you have to decide where to put your limited resource.  Even choosing how often and when to rest effects gameplay.The combat is isometric turn-based, and involves a lot of strategy, and can at times, be surprisingly challenging.  There are three game modes, to provide more or less challenge to the player.  Hard mode being very challenging indeed.Overall an enjoyable experience that will leave you wanting more.  As soon as I finished the game, I began researching if there was to be a sequel, and I was pleased to hear the play is for this game to be part of a trilogy.Definitely worth playing, and highly recommended.
